entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 3 at 9:33AM CDT until April 4 at 9:00AM CDT by NWS Quad Cities IA IL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Watch continues for the following rivers in Illinois...
Pecatonica River at Freeport affecting Stephenson County.
.Uncertainty with routed flow from recent rains means confidence in the river reaching flood stage is low at this time. If the current forecast holds through early afternoon, a warning may be issued.
* WHAT...Flooding is possible.
* WHERE...Pecatonica River at Freeport.
* WHEN...From this evening to late tomorrow morning.
* IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Flood Stage. Water affects low lying sections of Freeport mainly east of the Pecatonica River.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 AM CDT Wednesday the stage was 12.1 feet. - Forecast...Flood stage may be reached tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING TO LATE TOMORROW MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 10:33AM EDT until April 4 at 11:25AM EDT by NWS Charleston WV
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Ohio...
Muskingum River At McConnelsville affecting Morgan and Washington Counties.
For the Muskingum River...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Muskingum River at McConnelsville.
* WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning.
* IMPACTS...At 11.6 feet, Most primary roads flooded in and between McConnelsville and Zanesville; several cottage-type homes are affected. At 12.0 feet, Many areas are flooded in and around McConnelsville. At 13.0 feet, Several homes and businesses start to flood in and around McConnelsville.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 13.1 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:00 AM EDT Wednesday was 13.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late tonight and continue falling to 10.6 feet Monday morning. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.8 feet on 08/12/1980. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued April 3 at 10:31AM EDT until April 3 at 11:15AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
At 1030 AM EDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line extending from near Watertown to near Bell, moving east at 40 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and penny size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
Locations impacted include... Lake City, Lake Butler, Bell, Raiford, Worthington Spring, Columbia, Alachua, Macclenny, High Springs, and Fort White.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 3 at 10:29AM EDT until April 4 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Buffalo NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of western New York, including the following counties, Allegany, Cattaraugus, Chautauqua, Genesee, Livingston, Monroe, Niagara, Northern Erie, Orleans, Southern Erie and Wyoming.
* WHEN...Through Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - So far between an inch and inch and a half of rain has fallen in the Allegheny River and Upper Genesee River basins, which is causing rises on these rivers. An additional inch of rain is possible during the day today, which may cause minor flooding depending on how much rain falls.
A quarter to half inch of rain fell in the Buffalo Creeks area last night and around a half inch in the Rochester area. An additional inch of rain is possible during today. Depending how much rain falls, this will cause rises on these creeks, with a small risk of generally minor flooding as these creeks respond to the rainfall tonight into Thursday. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Niagara; Orleans; Monroe; Northern Erie; Genesee; Wyoming; Livingston; Chautauqua; Cattaraugus; Allegany; Southern Erie

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH THURSDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 3 at 10:28AM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
At 1028 AM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along a line extending from near Bell to 16 miles southwest of Steinhatchee. Movement was east at 25 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Cross City, Steinhatchee, Horseshoe Point, Suwannee, Horseshoe Beach, Tennille, Shamrock, Clara, Cross City Airport, Shired Island, Old Town, Guaranto Springs, Jena, Hines, Jonesboro, Eugene, Fletcher, Yellow Jacket, and Fanning Springs.

entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Illinois...
Rock River near Joslin affecting Whiteside, Henry IL and Rock Island Counties.
Rock River at Moline affecting Henry IL and Rock Island Counties.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Rock River at Moline.
* WHEN...From late tonight until further notice.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued April 3 at 10:11AM AST until April 4 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip current conditions due to breaking waves up to 6 to 7 feet.
* WHERE...Beaches along the northwestern coastline of Puerto Rico from Aguadilla to Arecibo.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety. High waves that can wash over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Rip currents can occur anywhere you have breaking waves, like sandy beaches on the open ocean, but can also occur where there are solid structures,like jetties and piers or even rocks jutting out into the ocean.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH LATE TONIGHT

entry.summary:

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 8:59AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Suwannee, Gilchrist and Columbia Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Thursday morning at 900 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 17.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 17.8 feet Sunday evening. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Large snow drifts will form.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 8:01AM EDT until April 6 at 2:57PM EDT by NWS Charleston WV
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Charleston WV has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in West Virginia...Ohio...
Ohio River At Marietta Pumphouse affecting Wood, Pleasants and Washington Counties.
For the Ohio River...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Marietta Pumphouse.
* WHEN...From this morning to early Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 35.0 feet, Stark Street at 7th Street, Pike Street at Wayne, Elmwood Avenue and Greene Street at the center of Don Drumm Field are flooded. At 36.0 feet, Pike Street at the entrance to Phillips Elementary School, Elmwood Avenue and Hart Street start to flood. Eighth at Ohio and Stark Streets start to flood. Second and Third Streets between Green and Butler floods. At 37.0 feet, Hart Street at Ash and Fourth Streets, Stark and Jefferson Streets at Seventh Street, Fourth Street at Butler Street, Second and Third Streets at Church Street, Spike Streeet at Olney Street, Lafayette and Wayne Streets at Eighth Street, Greene Street at Fifth and Sixth Streets are flooded. At 38.0 feet, Elmwood Avenue at Ash, Hart, Pike and Charles Streets at Seventh Street, Church at Second Street, Butler at Fifth Street, Ohio Street at Second and Third Streets are all flooded. At 39.0 feet, Pike street at Lafayette, Greene at Third Street, Jefferson Street at East Eight Street, Third Street between Butler and Church Streets, and Second Street at Wooster Street are all flooded. At 40.0 feet, Major flooding is occurring. Wayne Street at Eighth Street, Greene Street at Second, Seventh and Pike Streets, Front Street at Monroe Street and at the Armory, Pennsylvania Avenue at Linwood Street and at Eton Street, Second Street at Bbutler Street, and Scammel Street at Second and Third Streets are all flooded. On the West Side, Harmar Street at Maple and Pearl Streets, and Market Street at Fort Square are flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 33.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 33 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this morning to a crest of 39.9 feet tomorrow evening. It will then fall below flood stage Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 35.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 39.6 feet on 02/18/2018. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Washington, OH; Pleasants, WV; Wood, WV

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS MORNING TO EARLY SATURDAY AFTERNOON

entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Charleston WV has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in West Virginia...Ohio...
Ohio River At Parkersburg affecting Wood and Washington Counties.
For the Ohio River...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Parkersburg.
* WHEN...From this afternoon to late Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 36.0 feet, Backwater effects will start to cause problems along the Little Kanawha River. Happy Valley Road in Happy Valley starts to flood. At 38.0 feet, Several homes flooded in the Happy Valley and Point Drive areas near Parkersburg, along the Little Kanawha River. A few homes are flooded on Annas Drive in Vienna, West Virginia. Dave's Marina, Walnut Street, and Scott Avenue in Belpre, Ohio, start to flood. At 40.0 feet, Most of Happy Valley is flooded. Sections of Vienna, West Virginia along the Ohio River are flooded. Walnut and John Streets in Belpre, Ohio are flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 33.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 35.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this afternoon to a crest of 39.9 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 36.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 39.7 feet on 02/18/2018. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 7:16AM EDT until April 7 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana...
Sugar Creek near Edinburgh.
Big Walnut Creek near Reelsville.
Mississinewa River near Ridgeville.
Eel River at Bowling Green.
Mill Creek near Cataract.
Driftwood River near Edinburgh.
Big Blue River at Shelbyville.
East Fork White River at Columbus to Seymour
Flatrock River near Columbus.
.Repeat rounds of showers and thunderstorms Monday and Tuesday or so brought 1 to 4 inches of rainfall to most parts of central and southern Indiana. This is bringing rises to area waterways. Minor flooding is expected at most or all locations, but isolated moderate flooding is possible. Persons with interests along area rivers should closely monitor forecasts for updates.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...East Fork White River at Seymour.
* WHEN...From this morning to Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Extensive lowland flooding affecting agricultural lands. Many county and state roads in flood plain become impassable by high water, including SR 235 East of Medora, SR 258 East of Cortland, CR 725 N and possibly SR 39 south of Tampico. High water affects county roads near Vallonia and Shields, Ewing Road near Brownstown, CR 525 N near Seymour wastewater treatment plant, Honeytown Road and possibly SR 250 east of Dudleytown and SR 256 west of Austin.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:45 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 10.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this morning to a crest of 16.2 feet tomorrow evening. entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana...
White River at Muncie to Ravenswood and Centerton to Edwardsport.
.Repeat rounds of showers and thunderstorms Monday and Tuesday or so brought 1 to 4 inches of rainfall to most parts of central and southern Indiana. This is bringing rises to area waterways. Minor flooding is expected at most or all locations, but isolated moderate flooding is possible. Persons with interests along area rivers should closely monitor forecasts for updates.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...White River at Newberry.
* WHEN...From this morning to Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 17.0 feet, Flood waters block access and begins to surround about 5 to 10 river cabins on south side of the river just southwest of Newberry.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:30 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 12.3 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage late this morning to 17.3 feet early Friday morning. It will then fall below flood stage Sunday morning to 6.7 feet early Tuesday morning. It will rise to 6.8 feet Tuesday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 3 at 6:23AM EDT until April 3 at 11:00AM EDT by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of central Pennsylvania, including the following counties, Blair, Cambria, Centre, Clearfield, Huntingdon, Juniata and Mifflin.
* WHEN...Until 1100 AM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways. River and stream flows are elevated and continue to rise, with smaller streams exceeding or forecast to exceed flood stage in some locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 619 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated a large area of heavy rain moving northeast across the region this morning with a few embedded thunderstorms. This is causing urban and small stream flooding. Between 0.7 and 1.5 inches of rain have fallen across the Advisory Area overnight. - Additional rainfall of 0.5 to 1 inch is expected over the area during the mid to late morning hours today, with locally heavier amounts of 1.5 inches where thunderstorms occur. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Altoona, State College, Johnstown, Lewistown, DuBois, Huntingdon, Clearfield, Bellefonte, Hollidaysburg, Tyrone, Westmont, Ebensburg, Belmont, Nanty-Glo, Portage, Sandy, Park Forest Village, Woodward, Northern Cambria and Boalsburg. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 3 at 3:04AM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* A strong cold front will move through the Sierra and western NV tonight and Thursday, bringing gusty winds, much colder temperatures, and chances for snow showers.
* Gusty southwest winds will develop this afternoon north of Highway 50 and shift to the Eastern Sierra of Mono and Mineral counties overnight into Thursday morning. This will impact outdoor activities, produce bumpy airplane rides, and cause gusty cross winds for high-profile vehicles, especially along Highway 395, Highway 95, and I-580. Wind gusts along the Sierra crest will exceed 80 mph.
* Snow showers will increase in northeast CA and the Sierra today and spread across the region tonight through Friday. Roads will be slick in the Sierra, especially at night. The higher April sun angle will limit accumulations during the daytime hours. Prepare for possible delays if your plans include travel across the Sierra. Total snow accumulations: Above 7000 feet in Greater Lake Tahoe: greater than 6 inches on the west side of Lake Tahoe and 1 to 2 inches in the Carson Range. Above 7000 feet in Mono County: 3 to 8 inches. Below 7000 feet in Mono County: a trace up to 4 inches. Lowest Nevada valleys: light snow showers, but little or no accumulation.
* Unusually cold air will settle into the area for early April with daytime temperatures 15-20 degrees below normal Thursday and Friday and only warming slightly over the weekend. Hard freezes are almost a certainty each night, even for lower western NV valleys beginning Thursday night. Be ready to protect sensitive plants and wrap exposed irrigation systems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Surprise Valley California; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area; Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake; Northern Washoe County

cap:parameter.value: PERIOD OF COLD AND UNSETTLED WEATHER THROUGH THE WEEKEND

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 5:24AM EDT until April 5 at 10:24AM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...Forecast flooding changed from Moderate to Major severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Ohio...
Wills Creek At Cambridge affecting Guernsey County.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wills Creek at Cambridge.
* WHEN...Until late Friday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Overflowing of poor drainage and low lying areas will result in minor flooding along wills creek. At 16.0 feet, Basement flooding begins through floor drains and other sewer connections. Local interruptions in sanitary service may occur along Gordon's Run from 3rd Street to 6th Street. At 17.0 feet, Water overflows wills Creek Valley Road to a depth of 2 feet. Water reaches a depth of 1 foot on North Eighth Street. At 18.0 feet, Flood waters begin effecting apartments along Wills Creek Valley Road. Southgate Parkway will also begin flooding near Woodlawn Avenue. At 20.0 feet, Flood waters reach residential areas on the west side of Cambridge. At 22.0 feet, The North 8th Street Bridge near the school campus is impassable. Flood waters reach Wills Creek Valley Drive near the County Road 35 Bridge. The north side of Cambridge is close to being cut off from access. Water from Wills Creek will flood the west end of Cambridge.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:15 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 19.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 5:15 AM EDT Wednesday was 19.6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 20.5 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage early Friday morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 19.3 feet on 01/13/2005. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Blizzard Warning issued April 3 at 5:16AM EDT until April 3 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Marquette MI
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blizzard conditions expected. Additional snow accumulations of 5 to 24 inches, greatest over the higher terrain from the Huron Mountains to Negaunee with the least amounts near the Lake Superior shore. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph, strongest winds expected on Wednesday, especially near Lake Superior.
* WHERE...Baraga and Marquette Counties.
* WHEN...Until 8 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult to impossible. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The hazardous conditions will impact the morning and evening commutes. The combination of wet snow and gusty winds will bring down tree branches and cause power outages. Tree damage and power outages could become widespread.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 3 at 5:12AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Watch continues for the following rivers in Massachusetts...Rhode Island...Connecticut...
Charles River At Dover affecting Southeast Middlesex MA, Western Norfolk MA and Central Middlesex MA zones.
Pawtuxet River At Cranston affecting Southeast Providence RI, Eastern Kent RI, Northwest Providence RI and Western Kent RI zones.
Pawcatuck River At Westerly affecting Northern New London, Washington RI and Southern New London zones.
Taunton River Near Bridgewater affecting Northern Bristol MA and Western Plymouth MA zones.
Wood River At Hope Valley affecting Washington RI zone.
For the Charles River...including Dover...flooding is possible. For the Pawtuxet River...including Scituate Reservoir, Cranston... flooding is possible. For the Pawcatuck River...including Westerly...flooding is possible. For the Taunton River...including Bridgewater...flooding is possible. For the Wood River...including Hope Valley...flooding is possible.
* WHAT...Flooding is possible.
* WHERE...Taunton River near Bridgewater.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Backwater flooding from the Taunton River will cause flooding of lower Purchade Brook in Middleboro. This will cause Woloski Park to become impassable by most vehicles for an extended period of time. Beware of the dangers of crossing flooded roadways. The water may be deeper than you think. Floodwaters have the ability to damage roadways. Heed the advice of local officials, and evacuate if asked to do so.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:45 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 7.4 feet. - Forecast...Flood stage may be reached late tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 3 at 5:03AM EDT until April 3 at 11:00AM EDT by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of South-Central Pennsylvania, including the following counties, Bedford and Somerset.
* WHEN...Until 1100 AM EDT Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways. River or stream flows are elevated.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 457 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated areas of moderate to heavy rain, along with a few thunderstorms moving northeast across the region through the mid morning hours. This will cause small stream flooding. Between 0.4 and 0.7 inches of rain have fallen overnight. - Additional rainfall of 0.3 to 0.6 inch is expected over the area through 9 AM. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Somerset, Windber, Bedford, Breezewood, Meyersdale, Berlin, Clearville, New Enterprise, Everett, Friedens, Boswell, Osterburg, Davidsville, Central City, Paint, Jerome, Buffalo Mills, Acosta, Ursina and Coaldale. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring.

Punxsutawney, Brookville, Reynoldsville, Brockway, Sykesville, Falls Creek, Big Run, Summerville, Rossiter, Timblin, Worthville, Knox-Dale and Anita. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 4:24AM EDT until April 4 at 3:12AM EDT by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Cleveland OH has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Ohio...
Blanchard River Near Findlay affecting Hancock County.
Maumee River At Waterville affecting Wood and Lucas Counties.
For the Blanchard River...including Findlay...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Maumee River...including Waterville...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Blanchard River near Findlay.
* WHEN...Until late tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Flooding impacts areas near Riverside Park and East Main Cross Street in the City of Findlay. Flooding on County Road 223 and portions of Howard Street. Water approaching some properties on Liberty Street and Apple Alley.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:00 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 11.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 8.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this morning to a crest of 12.4 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late this evening. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - Flood History...No available flood history. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 3 at 3:05AM CDT until April 3 at 10:00AM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
entry.summary:
...Heavy Wet Snow and Strong Winds Impacting Travel Into The Morning Commute...
.Narrow bands of snow seen overnight expected to continue into the morning commute. Snowfall rates of 0.5" per hour seen within these heavier bands, decreasing visibilities below 1 mile at times. These stronger snowfall bands depart to the east through central Wisconsin today. Additional accumulations of 1 to 4 inches expected area wide.
Increased wind gusts from 40 to 50 mph will exacerbate visibility reductions. Additionally, the combination of strong winds with heavier snow can fell tree branches or power lines.
Travel will be impacted through the morning commute, especially untreated roads and cooler ridge tops. Exercise caution.
* WHAT...Additional snow accumulations of up to two inches. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Portions of northeast Iowa, southeast Minnesota and central, north central, southwest and west central Wisconsin.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM CDT this morning.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions will impact the morning commute.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Winneshiek; Allamakee; Clayton; Winona; Fillmore; Houston; Taylor; Clark; Trempealeau; Jackson; La Crosse; Crawford; Grant

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued April 3 at 4:00AM EDT until April 3 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 3:40AM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Ohio...
Stillwater Creek At Uhrichsville affecting Tuscarawas County.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Stillwater Creek at Uhrichsville.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 5.0 feet, Stillwater Creek comes out of its banks in several locations resulting in overflowing in poor drainage areas. Minor flooding of low lying areas begins. At 6.5 feet, Flood waters of Stillwater Creek will reach the intersection of East 12th Street and North Main Street in Uhrichsville and approach Newport Street. Little Stillwater Creek will flood most of Phac Park along with portions of Wilson Road in Dennison. At 7.9 feet, Numerous low land areas are flooded. Stillwater Creek begins to flood portions of Newport Street in Uhrichsville. Homes along Park Drive begin to flood. Sections of Wilson Road near Phac Park are flooded. At 8.3 feet, Flood waters reach Newport Avenue in Uhrichsville as well as East 12th Street and North Main Street half way to East 11th Street. Phac Park along Little Stillwater Creek in Dennison is flooded. At 10.0 feet, Stillwater Creek comes out of its banks in several locations resulting in overflowing in poor drainage areas. Minor flooding of low lying areas begins. At 11.5 feet, Flood waters of Stillwater Creek will reach the intersection of East 12th Street and North Main Street in Uhrichsville and approach Newport Street. Little Stillwater Creek will flood most of Phac Park along with portions of Wilson Road in Dennison. At 12.8 feet, Flooding occurs in the west and north side of Uhrichsville (Main Street, West 5th Street, the east end of 4th Street, and the east end of Franklin Street.) Also flooded are areas in Uhrichsville and Dennison along Little Stillwater Creek and the west end of Newport. At 12.9 feet, Numerous low land areas are flooded. Stillwater Creek begins to flood portions of Newport Street in Uhrichsville. Homes along Park Drive begin to flood. Sections of Wilson Road near Phac Park are flooded. At 13.3 feet, Flood waters reach Newport Avenue in Uhrichsville as well as East 12th Street and North Main Street half way to East 11th Street. Phac Park along Little Stillwater Creek in Dennison is flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 13.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.6 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:00 AM EDT Wednesday was 13.4 feet. - Forecast...The river will fall to 13.1 feet this morning. It will then rise to 13.6 feet tomorrow morning. It will fall to 10.5 feet early Saturday afternoon. It will then rise to 10.8 feet early Sunday afternoon. It will fall again but remain above flood stage. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood History...No available flood history. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 3:39AM EDT until April 3 at 12:15PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Ohio...
Muskingum River At Coshocton affecting Coshocton County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring.
* WHERE...Muskingum River at Coshocton.
* WHEN...Until this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Water reaches low lying areas between Tuscarawas and Walhonding Rivers just upstream of the confluence of the two rivers. At 15.0 feet, Low areas are flooded and water reaches a few homes along Route 16 south of Coshocton and along County Route 1A north of Coshocton. At 16.0 feet, Flood waters begin to affect the Lake Park area along the Walhonding River and begins backwater flooding along Mill Creek north of Lake Park and along Route 83. Flood waters will begin to enter yards in low-lying areas along County Route 1A.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 15.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:00 AM EDT Wednesday was 16.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this morning and continue falling to 14.7 feet Sunday evening. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 15.2 feet on 02/18/2019. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 3 at 3:38AM EDT until April 4 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow and sleet expected. Total snow accumulations between 7 and 18 inches and sleet accumulations up to around one third of an inch. Localized amounts up to around 24 inches are possible, especially across higher terrain. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph.
* WHERE...Portions of south central, southwest, west central, and western Maine and central and northern New Hampshire.
* WHEN...From 2 PM this afternoon to 8 PM EDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Moderate snow with periods of heavy snow with potential for a foot plus of accumulation will create hazardous travel conditions across the region. Strong gusty winds are expected with the snowstorm, which could cause damage to trees and power lines. Travel is not recommended as heavy snowfall and very low visibility will create extremely dangerous driving conditions. The hazardous conditions will impact the evening and Thursday morning commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...This is a expected to be a long-duration, multi-faceted event. While precipitation starts today, intensity will increase tonight into Thursday when some of the heaviest rates may fall accompanied by strong, gusty winds. Be prepared for a prolonged duration of impact.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Watch issued April 3 at 3:37AM EDT until April 4 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...One to two feet of inundation above ground level possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways (4.5 to 13.4 feet Mean Lower Low Water).
* WHERE...Eastern Essex, Suffolk, Eastern Norfolk, Eastern Plymouth, Barnstable, Dukes and Nantucket Counties.
* WHEN...Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...Shallow pockets of flooding less than one foot deep affects the lowest lying areas along the coast, including Morrissey Boulevard in Boston. Most roads remain passable. Flooding up to one foot deep affects coastal roads on the North Shore from Salem to Gloucester and Newburyport. Rough surf will cause flooding on some coastal roads around the time of high tide due to splashover. Roads remain passable. Low lying areas and roads near Nantucket Harbor, including Easy Street, may experience pockets of shallow flooding less than one foot deep. Some roads become impassable. Flooding 1 to 2 feet deep affects low lying areas around Edgartown Harbor, Vineyard Haven, and Oak Bluffs. This includes the Chappy Ferry Dock in Edgartown, Five Corners and Beach Road in Vineyard Haven, and East Chop Drive in Oak Bluffs. Splashover from waves affects Sea View Avenue in Oak Bluffs.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 3 at 3:37AM EDT until April 4 at 6:00PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of northern Delaware, including the following area, New Castle, New Jersey, including the following areas, Camden, Gloucester, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Morris, Northwestern Burlington, Salem, Somerset, Sussex, Warren and Western Monmouth, and Pennsylvania, including the following areas, Berks, Carbon, Delaware, Eastern Chester, Eastern Montgomery, Lehigh, Lower Bucks, Monroe, Northampton, Philadelphia, Upper Bucks, Western Chester and Western Montgomery.
* WHEN...Through Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Additional rainfall amounts between 1.0 to 3.0 inches are expected across the Watch area into Thursday. About two dozen of our river points are forecast to approach flood stage today into Thursday, with several exceeding flood stage. The rain will be heavy at times, with hourly rates reaching or exceeding an inch, with the more widespread and heaviest rain expected to fall this afternoon and early this evening. During the higher rainfall rates, local flash flooding cannot be ruled out. Excessive runoff may continue to cause rivers, creeks, and streams to rise through the end of the week even when the rain has ended. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued April 3 at 1:14AM MDT until April 5 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT LATE MORNING THROUGH MID EVENING FRIDAY FOR THE NORTHWEST PLATEAU, RIO GRANDE VALLEY, SANDIA AND MANZANO MOUNTAINS BELOW SNOWPACK AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY AND AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE...
.Widespread critical fire weather conditions appear likely on Friday as winds increase ahead of an approaching storm system. These strong winds combined with low humidity will allow for rapid fire spread in dry and receptive fuels. Strong south to southwest winds will peak during the afternoon hours, but will remain elevated through the evening and overnight Friday night.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Fire Weather Watch...which is in effect from Friday morning through Friday evening.
* AREA AND TIMING...This includes the Northwest Plateau (Zone 101), Upper Rio Grande Valley and Lower Chama River Valley (Zone 121), Middle Rio Grande Valley (Zone 106), Sandia and Manzano Mountains below snowpack (Zone 124) and all of eastern New Mexico (Zones 104, 123, 125, and 126) from late Friday morning through Friday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...South to southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts between 40 and 50 mph. The strongest winds are expected across central and western New Mexico, with lighter winds across the eastern plains.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 8 and 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northwest Plateau; Northeast Plains; Middle Rio Grande Valley; Upper Rio Grande Valley and Lower Chama River Valley; Northeast Highlands; Sandia and Manzano Mountains; Central Highlands; East Central Plains

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY MORNING THROUGH FRIDAY EVENING

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 3 at 3:04AM EDT until April 5 at 6:00AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow and mixed precipitation expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 7 inches and ice accumulations of a light glaze. Winds gusting as high as 50 mph prior to wintry precipitation Wednesday evening.
* WHERE...Southeastern St. Lawrence County.
* WHEN...From 11 AM Wednesday to 6 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Thursday morning. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The heaviest snow is likely to occur Wednesday night into Thursday. In the afternoon, snow accumulations are more likely on grassy surfaces and elevated terrain than on roadways.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southeastern St. Lawrence; Southwestern St. Lawrence; Grand Isle; Western Franklin; Western Chittenden; Western Addison; Western Rutland

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM THIS MORNING TO 6 AM EDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 3 at 3:04AM EDT until April 5 at 6:00AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 15 inches, locally 18 to 24 inches. Winds gusting as high as 50 mph prior to heavy snow Wednesday evening.
* WHERE...Portions of northern New York and northeast Vermont.
* WHEN...From 11 AM Wednesday to 6 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Travel on mountain passes may be impossible at times due to localized blizzard and whiteout conditions, especially overnight tonight. The hazardous conditions is most likely to impact the Thursday morning commute. Strong winds could cause tree damage.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The heaviest snow is likely to occur Wednesday night into Thursday. Snowfall rates could exceed 1 inch per hour at times. During the afternoon hours, snow accumulations are more likely on grassy surfaces and elevated terrain than on roadways.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern St. Lawrence; Northern Franklin; Eastern Clinton; Southern Franklin; Western Clinton; Western Essex; Eastern Essex; Orleans; Essex; Lamoille; Caledonia; Washington; Orange; Eastern Franklin; Eastern Chittenden; Eastern Addison; Eastern Rutland; Western Windsor; Eastern Windsor

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 3 at 2:41AM EDT until April 4 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of central Pennsylvania, including the following areas, Adams, Bedford, Blair, Cambria, Cameron, Clearfield, Columbia, Cumberland, Dauphin, Elk, Franklin, Fulton, Huntingdon, Juniata, Lancaster, Lebanon, McKean, Mifflin, Montour, Northern Centre, Northern Clinton, Northern Lycoming, Northumberland, Perry, Potter, Schuylkill, Snyder, Somerset, Southern Centre, Southern Clinton, Southern Lycoming, Sullivan, Tioga, Union, Warren and York.
* WHEN...Through Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Creeks and streams are running high especially across south central Pennsylvania and could flood with more heavy rain. Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Additional rainfall amounts of 1.5 to 2.5 inches on top of the 1 to 4 inches of rain that has already fallen will maintain an elevated risk of inundation and river flooding across central Pennsylvania. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Warren; McKean; Potter; Elk; Cameron; Northern Clinton; Clearfield; Northern Centre; Southern Centre; Cambria; Blair; Huntingdon; Mifflin; Juniata; Somerset; Bedford; Fulton; Franklin; Tioga; Northern Lycoming; Sullivan; Southern Clinton; Southern Lycoming; Union; Snyder; Montour; Northumberland; Columbia; Perry; Dauphin; Schuylkill; Lebanon; Cumberland; Adams; York; Lancaster

* WHERE...Youghiogheny River at Sutersville.
* WHEN...From this morning to late Thursday morning.

At 23.0 feet, Floodwaters reach the railroad tracks on the left bank.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 4:41PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north into the Chukchi Sea on Wednesday will bring water levels up 2 feet along the coast starting Wednesday evening and continuing into Thursday. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for many of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 4:41PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north across the Bering Sea tonight and Wednesday will bring water levels up 2 to 4 feet along the coast from the Bering Strait south on Wednesday and continuer into Thursday. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. Ice could push onto the beach along south facing coast lines. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for most of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 2:37PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* A strong cold front will move through the Sierra and western NV late Wednesday through Thursday and bring gusty winds, much colder temperatures, and chances for snow showers.
* Gusty southwest winds will develop Wednesday afternoon north of US-50 and shift to the Eastern Sierra of Mono and Mineral counties overnight into Thursday morning. This will impact outdoor activities, produce bumpy airplane rides, and cause gusty cross winds for high-profile vehicles, especially along US-395, US-95, and I-580. Wind gusts along the Sierra crest will exceed 80 mph.
* Snow showers will increase in northeast CA and the Sierra Wednesday and spread across the region Wednesday night through Friday. Roads will be slick in the Sierra, especially at night. The higher April sun angle will limit accumulations during the daytime hours. Prepare for possible delays if your plans include travel across the Sierra. Total snow accumulations: Above 7000 feet in Greater Lake Tahoe: greater than 6 inches on the west side of Lake Tahoe and 1-2 inches in the Carson Range. Above 7000 feet in Mono County: 3-8 inches. Below 7000 feet in Mono County: trace-4 inches. Lowest Nevada valleys: light snow showers, but no accumulation.
* Unusually cold air will settle into the area for early April with daytime temperatures 15-20 degrees below normal Thursday and Friday and only warming slightly over the weekend. Hard freezes are almost a certainty each night, even for lower western NV valleys beginning Thursday night. Be ready to protect sensitive plants and wrap exposed irrigation systems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Surprise Valley California; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area; Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake; Northern Washoe County

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 2 at 4:52PM EDT until April 4 at 11:30AM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Hudson River caused by storm surge and rainfall during times of high tide Wednesday afternoon and particularly early thursday morning.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast New York, including the following counties, Orange, Putnam, Rockland and Westchester.
* WHEN...Until 1130 AM EDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in vulnerable riverfront communities. Expect around 1 to 2 ft of inundation above ground level in low lying, vulnerable areas. This will result in scattered road closures and cause widespread flooding of low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns and homes/businesses and basements near the waterfront. Vehicles parked in vulnerable areas near the waterfront will likely become flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 440 PM EDT, National Weather Service New York NY has issued this Flood Advisory with expectation of flooding along the Hudson River during the times of high tide Wednesday afternoon into Thursday morning, caused by storm surge and rainfall. - In addition rainfall amounts of 2 to 3 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will exacerbate flooding issues. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Stony Point, Piermont, Cold Spring, Croton On The Hudson, Garrison Landing, Newburgh, Ossining and Cortland. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued April 2 at 3:23PM EDT until April 3 at 7:00PM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, around 1 ft of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline. For the Coastal Flood Warning, around 2 ft of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline.
* WHERE...Southern Queens County.
* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, from 2 PM to 7 PM EDT Wednesday. For the Coastal Flood Warning, from 3 AM to 7 AM EDT Thursday.
* COASTAL FLOOD IMPACTS...Widespread minor to moderate flooding of vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline Wed night. Expect around 2 ft of inundation above ground level in low lying, vulnerable areas. This will result in numerous road closures and cause widespread flooding of low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns and homes/businesses with basements near the waterfront. Vehicles parked in vulnerable areas near the waterfront will likely become flooded. Flooding will also extend inland from the waterfront along tidal rivers and bays.
* SHORELINE IMPACTS...Breaking waves of 4 to 8 ft Wednesday into Thursday morning, along with elevated water levels, will result in beach flooding and erosion. Scattered areas of dune erosion are possible during the times of high tide Wed afternoon into Thursday morning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of heavy rain and elevated water levels on Wednesday afternoon into evening may cause localized flash flooding along some shoreline roads and properties. The coverage and magnitude of flooding late Wednesday Night will be dependent on track of low pressure, and timing of windshift from easterly gales to northwest gales. This will be refined over the next 24 hours.

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued April 2 at 1:37PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
AVAGYX
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center, Gorham NH.
The US Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center has issued a backcountry avalanche watch. This avalanche watch does not apply to operating ski areas.
* WHAT...A significant winter storm, bringing the possibility of 30+ inches of snow and strong wind to the higher summits in the Presidential Range, will create dangerous avalanche conditions.
* WHERE...The Presidential Range avalanche forecast area, including but not limited to Tuckerman Ravine, Huntington Ravine, Gulf of Slides, Great Gulf, King Ravine, Burt Ravine, Ammonoosuc Ravine, Oakes Gulf and steep, open terrain in the mountains that are bounded by US Rt 2, US Rt 302, and NH Rt 16. This includes hiking trails that traverse across steep terrain like Summer Lion Head trail. Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside of the coverage area where steep, open terrain exists that has collected drifted snow.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 16:00 EDT to Fri 16:00 EDT.
* IMPACTS... Large, destructive avalanches are likely to occur naturally and spontaneously and will exist throughout steep terrain including hiking trails. These avalanches may be large enough to bury multiple people, do significant damage to trees or buildings, and will likely run far down in paths or areas that are normally safe zones. Precipitation rates are forecast to be heavy, with 1-2 inches of snow falling per hour at times and visibility limited.
